post: How do you guys avoid spikes after eating?

comments.text:
Physical activity helps immensely. I will often go for a walk or do some light exercise shortly after eating and the difference in my post meal spikes between I do it vs when I don't is significant.

I also sometimes [super bolus](https://www.diabetesnet.com/diabetes-technology/blue-skying/super-bolus/), which is where you add your next couple of hours worth of basal insulin on to your bolus and then do a 0% temp rate on your basal for that time. That's helpful when I know the food will spike me quickly.

It’s possible 15 minutes isn’t enough of a prebolus. You could try increasing it by a minute or two and seeing if your spike height changes. 

I’m on Lyumjev, one of the fastest insulins on the market and I need to give it a 25 minute prebolus to keep my spike down.

I’d add five more minutes to the prebolus. Mine takes close to 25 minutes.  You can also over-bolus and back off your basal later, but I haven’t gotten to try that yet because I’m MDI.

I also stuck a water bottle next to my pens and I drink water when I take the insulin. It has helped my prebolus time.

Eat less during meals but have small snacks between meals.

Another useful thing to do is to manage basal(s). I use different basal rates for different activities e.g., sleep, sedentary day, and varying levels of physical activity.

Sometimes 15 minutes isn’t enough time depending on what you eat! For fatty meals I barely pre-bolus while stuff like cookies/cake I have to wait like 30-40 minutes before eating cause it hits me super fast. Try waiting a little longer and see if that helps. If not, perhaps your ratio isn’t quite dialed in. Keep in mind it’s not uncommon for your ratio to change throughout the day. Mine is wack in the mornings, lower in the afternoons and pretty normal in the evenings.

Depending on which way you blood is going I find a short walk after eating helps get the insulin working. If your trending down it will lead to a low. If I take insulin and eat with no exercise my blood goes high no matter what I take
I use 45 minutes to treat before eating carbs. 15 minutes for protein. Honestly was surprised how well it worked when it was suggested.

How do I keep omni pod secure
So I’m new to omni pod and I don’t get how people don’t have them ripped off constantly. I’ve had it for 2 weeks and have already had 2 get ripped off from either a corner of a wall or the dining room table. Is there a product that hold it on better? Is something to put under a patch to make it more rigid and durable. I will start using a patch more but it don’t seem secure enough.

Also how do you guys sleep with it on your stomach? It’s so annoying. Is that something I will eventually get use to?

comments.text: It’s part of why I quit the omnipod. It’s just SO massive.
I keep it on my lower back actually so sleeping on my stomach is no problem at all. Maybe try some other places you can put the pod to see what works better for you?

Sleeping you’ll get used to! It takes time but eventually you’ll be able to ignore that part.

As for hitting it on stuff, try angling your pod differently. If mines on my stomach, I like to have it horizontal or sometimes I’ll go diagonal up or down but far away from my love handles. Arm is tricky sometimes (I accidentally pulled mine off when taking my bra off once 😂) and thigh I just don’t like. Back I’ve never had an issue. You’ll get the hang of it and eventually you won’t hit it all the time!

There’s not much you can do to keep it on if you catch it and rip it off. But it does happen less eventually. When I started (12ish years ago) I would hit it all the time. On my arm, it was doorframes, and on my leg, it was… everything. The worst was ripping it clean off on a school bus seat. Over time I got used to it and now I hardly ever hit it, and when I do it’s just slightly.

I bought bands that I use while sleeping for my arms because I'm a restless sleepers that covers that pod( almost similar to stretchy under armor but slightly tighter) or I'll use Vet wrap if desperate. I have actually had luck with using my chest  as a site lol apparently boobage absorbs insulin well for me.  As always SkinTac and Simpatch never seem to let me down and I usually have trouble pulling pod off after using SkinTac. Amazon sells different "belts, arms bands etc for runners that I've used in past that have been helpful.
We use [Pod Pals](https://sugarmedical.com/products/pod-pals-omnipod-adhesive-overlays) to help keep them on. They were recommended by Insulet.

post:
What about Sauna ?
Can we go to the sauna? The heat ? I’m lost with this disease and recently diagnosed

comments.text:
If you have a pump, or cgm you risk it falling off.
Otherwise I think you should be fine, but no telling unless you try it.
We are all different

Some people find that heat increases a cortisol response, which increases insulin resistance or blood sugars. Some people also see heat decreases insulin resistance making them go low. Generally speaking it's safe as long as you keep an eye on your blood sugars.

Yes! Same with hot tubs. Things to keep in mind are that heat and sweating often increases insulin sensitivity, so your insulin may be more effective than usual which could cause lows. As long as you keep an eye on it though, you’ll be fine.
Yea, and my experience is that the fsl2 start working after it get cold again. But if you use pump, i would take it of before the saune because insulin can get bad.
So for me it increased my sugars and then it goes down again

I just went to onsen in Japan last week. My libre stooped working for whole time I was in there, but started working again once the temperature evened out after I was back in hotel. If you have decent hypo sensitivity (I do), just go and have fun :D   


psa: ANY cgm can malfunction for a while/ show higher than normal/lower than normal readings while in extreme environment. Fingersticks highly recommended lol. I decided I'm fine running high-ish for a while and didn't bother.

I do it but it does drop my BG, similar to hot tub or hot shower.

Plan accordingly, check BV frequently, have a lot of snacks on hand. Have a care taker/someone with you who knows whats up in case you pass out.

How do you cope with hyperglycemias?
Hello, I'm 21M I currently live in Czech republic where I attend an university. Just half a year ago I moved away from my family and I live on my own in a rented apartment. I have diabetes for almost 11 years now but I find it increasingly difficult to manage it. Despite the fact that I'm doing literally everything I've been told by my doctor I cannot seem to cope with hyperglycemias. It's more frustrating now since I have important exams that will determine if I'll pass or not. I cannot concentrate, I'm restless even if I sleep longer than I should and learning anything is nearly impossible. I cannot even do the simplest tasks and it's also taking a great toll on my job. Is there anything I can possibly do to somehow supress hyperglycemias effectively in a short period of time? How do you deal with them? Any advice would be greatly appreciated.

comments.text: brisk walk does magic 🎩

Is there a pattern? Does the hyperglycemia occur at consistent times, for example after meals or overnight? If it is a regular, recurring thing, it might just mean that you need more insulin at those times. Do you adjust your doses on your own or wait for your doctor to do it? Does it happen when you are stressed at school, such as before an exam? That can be a little harder to control but if it's very consistent (happening every time you have an exam or presentation or whatever) then taking a bit of extra insulin then might also help until you get more used to the new activities and are less stressed by them. As someone else mentioned, a quick walk can also get the insulin working better.
Either exercise, get insulin, or drink water. I also eat snow sometimes.

Might seem totally unrelated but the “fight/flight” response kicks in automatically. Over the years it’s easily increased stress levels and subsequent cortisol levels that also affect BG. Breathing and grounding helps me. Doesn’t necessarily have a direct impact and I know only a bit of the physiology, however has helped with the balance a whole lot.
Highs are usually caused by too low basal dose, too low bolus dose, illness, stress and many other unknown factors. Fix one or more for better control.
Eating less/lower carbohydrates has done wonders for me

How's the iLet?
My endocrinologist is recommending that I switch from my Tandem T-Slim to an iLet. If you're using the iLet, how do you like it, and what kind of results are you getting?  Thanks!

comments.text:
I'd never heard of it so I googled it. What struck me the most was "no carb counting". According to the website: 

"No carb counting  
Instead of carb counting everything on your plate, the iLet just needs an estimate of the carbs in your meal – Usual for me, More or Less." [https://www.betabionics.com/ilet-bionic-pancreas/ilet-adults/](https://www.betabionics.com/ilet-bionic-pancreas/ilet-adults/) 

hmmm I dubious.
From what I read, the iLet will target a 7.0 a1c. If you are already under that the iLet would be worst

The iLet is really designed for people who don't want to think about their diabetes or don't/can't manage it well and just want something to work for them 

It's a good pump, but will cause havoc for the more advanced and well managed users.

If you go low you have to be super careful how much you treat, and if you're running high you're SOL and have to wait till the pump gives you enough insulin to get you back to target

Your Endo is correct in that it's GREAT for people who are at an A1C of 14 (fully unwilling to manage their diabetes) and can help bring them down to around a 7. For those who have tight control it would be a nightmare. I listened to an interview with the founder on The Juice box and he stated that "post meal of up to 270 was acceptable to their algorithm". I'm sorry, but if I'm at 205 I'm already range bolusing. If I'm over 220 or so I feel like death. I can't imagine being stuck at 250+ without the ability to bolus down.

The ilet is an amazing option for people who are burnt out and have dangerously high a1cs, children and teens who have very little parental support, people in a clinical setting (like a nursing home) who have subpar support from staff, people who have disordered eating whose issues are exacerbated by carb counting, and people with cognitive disabilities.

Here is an interview with the creater
https://www.juiceboxpodcast.com/episodes/jbp934

I think it will save countless lives for people who can no longer care for themselves (due to burnout or disability or lack of education on how to manage diabetes)

It's not a great fit for someone who needs tight control (a pregnant T1D, someone who has late stage kidney failure), someone on a very low carb diet, or someone who prefers very tight control.

My son has multiple disabilities (he's autistic with an intellectual disability) and we plan on switching to the ilet as he grows older, but for now he's pretty young and living at home so we have very good control on the OP5, and are happy with our current routine. We are not looking to switch anytime soon.

I'm really excited about the research that iLet is doing with a dual pump (that has both insulin and glucagon) but that's several years away from commercial use.
Everyone else's comment is completely on point, I just wanted to add another one that I think the ILet for you would be a big NO. Don't be afraid to assert yourself with your endo!

NO!!!!! Control IQ is a far superior algorithm to the iLet. The iLet has no way to adjust basal rates or give correction boluses. You just have to wait for the algorithm to figure it out. 

It averages maintaining an A1c of around 7, but many, many people hit 5s on the Tandem, which is basically a non-diabetic A1c.

How to get a good nights rest
I see most people on here complaining that there blood sugar goes down when they sleep while i have the opposite problem my blood sugar goes nothing but up during my sleep and idk what to do

comments.text: Do you have sleep apnea? I used to have bad sleep apnea and i think my body was releasing cortisol, sending my blood sugar straight up

Because your liver releases glucose at night while you sleep it happens to everyone even non diabetics but their pancreas works so it combats it to stays at a normal blood sugar. The only way you can control this as a diabetic is to have a insulin pump. Apparently their is another before bed shot you can take on top of your basil but my endo says it sucks. The pump is basically the most reliable healthy way to prevent this night time glucose rise.
Probably need to adjust your basil. Do you have a pump or do you use pens?
When people go low at night it’s sometimes too much basal I think. So maybe take more since you are experiencing the opposite if that makes sense. Or just ask your doctor.

When do you take your basal? If you take it on a morning you're possibly "running out" overnight. 

I take Lantus just before bed and in the last fortnight I've had to reduce by 8 units because of overnight lows, despite running high for months I've suddenly started to have lows.
Get a pump
You need to up your basal dosage. Do it by 1 unit a night until it levels off.
I didn’t  bc want a pump, either.  I’ve been on Omnipod for 6 weeks and it’s evened out my numbers and I feel much better.

post:
How to calculate the amount of insulin that you need?
Hi am newly diagnosed with T1, so I apologize if my question sounds stupid. 

How to do carb counting?

I am currently using Tresiba and apidra every before meals and I am experience a lot of low usually at night and it is annoying. 

How do I calculate the units of insulin I need. 

What is pre-bolus? and how to do it?

​

comments.text: What country are you in? Usually you should be able to go to a diabetes centre to receive proper and thorough education about how to handle your diabetes. More than anyone here could provide.

Usually a medical professional helps you figure out what your carb to insulin ratio is, and then you would just do the math to figure out how much insulin you need. 

Prebolusing just means to take your insulin and wait a period of time before you eat. The amount of time that works best varies, I find about 20 minutes before eating is ideal.
Contact your medical personnel about this!! But I’ll say that if you have lows at night it might indicate that the Tresiba dose is too high.

In addition to the above, if your Endocrinologist hasn’t reviewed this with you then I’d strongly recommend looking for a new Endo. You’re new to this and they should’ve ensured you have the basic down when they put you on these prescriptions. Glad you came here for support.

You might benefit from Juicebox podcast "pro series."

This does not replace seeking guidance from your endocrinology clinic team.  More like homework or self-study, so you can really maximize what you learn from your team.

Carb counting is done by reading the labels, looking up carb counts on the internet, with an app, or in a book. So if you eat a piece of steak and a cup of broccoli you look it up and learn that the steak has no carbs and the broccoli has the amount your app or book says. You will memorize many foods over time. Next you have to dose for any carbs you’re gonna eat. For every certain amount of carbs you will need a certain amount of insulin. That’s called a carb ratio and with some math you can calculate how much insulin you need at each meal. Except that your carb ratio might be different at different times of the day and you may need to add more insulin if you are high. Yes, it’s complicated but you will get it in time. If you are going low at night you probably have too much Tresiba. There are exceptions. Wake up at 12 and three to treat lows unless you have an odd bedtime or you wake to CGM alarms. A prebolus means you are dosing for food before you eat. You might dose five minutes to forty five min before depending on how high you are and how fast the food will be, etc. Only do this later when you know more. Did your doctor tell you to eat according to a meal plan where every meal is already set? If yes, just follow that plan until told otherwise. Don’t dose before bed unless you wont sleep through a low.

Pretty recently diagnosed here..
My endo told me to inject 1 unit of bolus (in my case apidra) for every 10 g of carbs. And for the random spikes during the day (without eating anything) is to inject 1-1.5 units for every 2 mmol/l to the normal level (e.g. if my sugar level is 11 mmol/l and I want to lower it to 5 mmol/l I have to inject 3-4 units)
Requires some math, but pretty accurate for me (so far))

How do you decide BG for before exercise ?
My 6yr old son does mtb training (pretty intense) We are always worried that he would go low in the middle, but on the other hand when he starts training he usually goes higher. 

We try to training to begin at 150 so we have enough margin. Today  he’s been pretty stable and went from 152 to 180 in the two hours. What’s your strategy to decide on a pre training target?

comments.text:
Not so intense, I just play table tennis with my buddies... And I do aim for around 150 (do you have a CGM? 150 and steady is very different from 150 and rapidly falling).

We usually start right after my work, making it a bit hard to squeeze in dinner before, thus I very often miss the 150. But anything under 110 and they're gonna have to start without me.

The type of exercise really affects me differently. Cardio and I'll drop like a rock. Weights and I'll go higher. With my pump (medtronic) I set a temp basal and it'll try to hold me at 150. Does he have a pump and/ or a CGM?
What is mtb training?

If you have insulin in your system, that will have more of an effect. If I exercise on an empty stomach first with zero insulin on board, effects on my BG are negligible. If I just had dinner and lots of insulin in me, BG will plummet. 

Just FYI.

Does he cycle to the top or get a lift and let gravity do its things on his way back down? The reason I ask is I do hill walking quite a lot. During the ascent I have to reduce my insulin by 50%-75% before I start or my bloods will plummet. However as I reach the top I resume my insulin as on my decent, there isn't much physical effort in comparison to the ascent and my bloods will shoot up otherwise.
Just let him be at 180. For me exercise tends to go similar. And then once I’m relaxing after training I crash down hard. A few hours at 180 won’t harm him or anything. I wouldn’t risk a hard crash
